VelocityDRIVE™ CT Installation Instructions

Introduction

This chapter provides the necessary steps to install VelocityDRIVE CT in both Windows and Linux environments. It also shows how to update the switch's firmware and confirm the firmware version number. For initial setup, the VelocityDRIVE SP evaluation board should be connected directly to the host PC via USB.

Note: A USB hub can introduce communication delays of up to 15 seconds. Microchip recommends connecting USB devices directly to your PC.

Software and Firmware Download

To obtain VelocityDRIVE CT software please visit http://www.microchip.com/mymicrochip and speak to your representative.

For more information and documentation on VelocityDRIVE SP, please visit https://microchip-ung.github.io/velocitydrivesp-documentation/index.html .

Windows

To install VelocityDRIVE CT, download and run the Microchip VelocityDRIVE CT Setup EXE installer. Once installation is complete, click the Microchip VelocityDRIVE CT shortcut (shown below) from the Start menu of your Windows system to launch the application.

Figure 2-1: Windows Start Menu Icon

To verify the VelocityDRIVE CT application version, use the Start menu to access Windows Settings.

Figure 2-2: Windows Settings Icon Location

Once Windows Setting is open, choose, Apps & Features. In the search field, input Microchip or VelocityDRIVE CT.

Figure 2-3: Version Number

Note: Alternatively, the software version number of your VelocityDRIVE CT application is also reported in the second entry of the Log tab via a TRACE command upon start up. More details can be found in Log Tab.

Alternatively, the software version number of your VelocityDRIVE CT application is also reported in the second entry of the Log tab via a TRACE command upon start up. More details can be found in Log View.

Linux

There are three options when installing VelocityDRIVE CT on the Linux platform:

  • Installation via snap package
  • Installation via AppImage package
  • Installation through unpacking the TAR archive

Please refer to the release note to confirm the correct executable filename of Microchip VelocityDRIVE CT.

If you will be communicating with the switch over a serial line, confirm that you have adequate permissions to access serial devices prior to installation. As shown in the following example code, it is required for the user to be a member of the dialout group to read and write to the device.

bash
                                $ ls -l /dev/ttyAC*
                                crw-rw---- 1 root dialout 166, 0 Apr 18 10:32 /dev/ttyACM0

In some Linux distributions, changing a user's group settings may require a logout/reboot from the OS for VelocityDRIVE CT's connection to be reestablished.

Microchip VelocityDRIVE CT tool is installed side-by-side, so no additional packages are required. VelocityDRIVE CT has been tested under Ubuntu 22.04.03 LTS.

A USB hub can introduce communication delays of up to 15 seconds. Microchip recommends connecting USB devices directly to your PC.

Firmware Update

Before using the VelocityDRIVE CT tool to configure a switch, you may desire to update the device's firmware. For the most up to date version of VelocityDRIVE SP firmware compatible with your device, follow the instructions on the SW Packets page of the VelocityDRIVE SP Documentation Site.

After acquiring the firmware image (*.FIP format), conenct the switch to your PC via USB, and start the VelocityDRIVE™ CT software:

Click on the Devices tab, as shown in Figure 2-4.

Figure 2-4: Devices Tab

Then, click the Upload button as shown in Figure 2-5.

Figure 2-5: Device Tab Upload Button

The Upload button opens a menu with several options:

Figure 2-6: Firmware Upload
  1. The first button contains a drop down that allows you to choose different types of uploads to your device. For the purposes of this section, please remain on Firmware Update.
  2. The second row confirms the type of CoAP Method command. For the purposes of this section, it will remain on PUT.
  3. The third row displays the type of Universal Resource Identifier (URI) you will be uploading
  4. The fourth button selects the firmware image to apply (this must be inthe *.FIP file format). Once selected, press the Upload button

A progress bar will appear below the Upload button. Do not power down the board until it has finished. Once the progress bar disappears, you can power cycle or reset the board to load the new firmware and confirm that the version has changed.

Note:

If changes have been made to a switch's startup configuration (See Section 4.6 “Configuration Upload”), we advise confirming that the customized configuration does not conflict with the latest firmware. Please reference the firmware change log. Additionally, a firmware update will not erase any custom changes made to a startup configuration unless a hard reset is performed. If it is found that conflicts occur between the custom startup configuration and the new firmware update, the custom configuration can be removed by performing a factory reset. To proceed, hold the reset button for 3 seconds to restore the default configuration from the firmware package

Firmware Version

A connected switch's firmware version can be read from its Device Card in the Devices tab as shown in Firmware Version . Please see Section 3.7.1: "Connecting a Device to VelocityDRIVE CT" for more information.

Figure 2-7: Firmware Version

Firmware Update - Alternate Method and Debricking Support

If the firmware on your device does not update as expected (as evidenced by a FAIL message in the VelocityDRIVE CT Log tab or the device no longer responds), an alternate update/debrick method may be required.

  1. Open a web browser and navigate to the VelocityDRIVE SP Documentation site .
  2. On the page's menu, navigate to the EVBs section.
  3. Identify your device from the list of supported evaluation boards.
  4. Under the Key Information column, click the debrick link that corresponds to your specific EVB model number.
  5. Follow the firmware flashing instructions on the Flashing and Debrick page.

For the most up to date version of VelocityDRIVE SP firmware, follow the documentation site above.

Quick Start

Quick Start Part 1 - Connecting Device Over IP

Device Setup

Power on your device. Connect the EVB to your machine via a USB connection and launch VelocityDRIVE CT. Then, navigate to the Devices tab.

Devices Tab

The EVB should be automatically found and displayed on a Device Card.

Troubleshooting EVB connection

If the device is not recognized, the EVB may not have the proper VelocityDRIVE SP firmware installed. Our VelocityDRIVE SP Online documentation provides steps for reflashing the firmware for your particular EVB (the sames steps are outlined above in Section 2.5.2 “Firmware Update - Alternate Method and Debricking Support”):

Explore - Devices Tab

After confirming your device's connection, it is ready for some simple changes. But first, follow these steps to make a back-up of your datastore, known as a configuration. Navigate to the Devices tab and click the Explore button as shown in Figure 2-9.

Use the Download button to export the unmodified device settings as a back-up (see Section 4.8.1 “Device State Export (CBOR, JSON)” for more information on available export formats).

Export of Original Device Configuration

Now that the back-up is complete, press the Copy Datastore button at the bottom of the Devices tab. This retrieves all configurable values from your device's YANG instance datastore into a default configuration file. Next, click the adjacent Open Configuration button. This opens the default configuration's root folder.

Create New Device Configuration

As shown in Figure 2-12, navigate to the Configurations tab's Name/Description sub-tab and under Configuration Name type in “CoAP Configuration” and click Update.

Naming Configuration

Remaining in the Configurations tab, switch back to the Values sub-tab. Using the menu on the left, navigate to the /root/coap-server/config container using the branching menu tree. You will see that the security-mode (enumeration) leaf is set to raw-public- key. Toggle the security-mode to no-sec.

CoAP Yang Tree Path

Navigate back to the /(root) container.

Upload Configuration

Save the current configuration as part of the device’s startup datastore by clicking the Upload button in the lower left Devices tab. If successful, you will receive a notification at the bottom of the screen, as shown in Figure 2-14. Reboot the device by tapping the reset button once (do not power cycle board, as the new startup configuration will be lost). Returning to the Devices tab, press the Refresh button.

Refresh - Devices Tab

Confirm the change has been made using the Explore button in the Device Card and navigating to the /root/coap-server/config container. The value of the security-mode leaf on the device should now be no-sec, indicating that the device is configured to use CoAP over UDP without any security options.

Note:

If the value did not appear to change on the device, use the Refresh button to the right of the value to send a FETCH command to obtain the current value (see Section 3.7.2 “Devices Tab Interface” for more details).

Next, return to the Configurations tab and navigate to /interfaces/interface. Delete all present interfaces (name=1, name=2, AGGR1, etc.). Use the Add Item button . Open interface[name=’_’]. For the Value in the name (string) row of the main panel, delete the dash and add L3V1. In the left panel, use the Clear button to remove all children nodes if present. In the YANG Elements selection sidebar menu, select ipv4 and use the Add Selected button to add it as a child node. Click on ipv4 and add the address YANG Element. Select it and press the Add Item button once again. The empty address container should now read address: ip=0.0.0.0. Click on it to open a leaf named ip (inet:ipv4-address-no-zone → string). Inside the empty IP address value in the main panel, enter the IP address of your choosing to assign to the switch (in accordance with your local Ethernet Network IP assignments). Return to the /(root) location of your configuration and add these new parameters to the startup configuration datastore by clicking the Upload button in the lower Devices Dashboard. Then, reboot the device by tapping the reset button once (do not power cycle board, as the new startup configuration will be lost). Press the Refresh button on the Device Card in the Devices tab. Confirm the change by visiting the /interfaces/interface/interface[ name=’L3V1]’/ipv4/address location on your device. You will see that the iPatch command only synced the interface you were adding, and did not make changes to the other interfaces in the tree. Removing the unchanged interfaces from the same branch level in your configuration ensures the patch change is isolated to only this single addition. Next, using your PC’s terminal, ping the IP address you assigned to your switch. Once successful, you may add the device’s network connection in the Devices tab as outlined below.
